questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Circumvallate papillae are large, dome-shaped papillae located at the posterior part of the tongue, arranged in a V-shape anterior to the sulcus terminalis. They have deep surrounding trenches (moats) lined by taste buds, which help in taste perception.

Von Ebner's glands, which secrete serous fluid to cleanse taste buds, are located at the base of the trenches.

Fungiform papillae (Option A): Mushroom-shaped papillae located scattered on the anterior tongue, mainly on the tip and sides. Contain taste buds on their apical surface but lack surrounding trenches.

Filiform papillae (Option C): Most numerous, thin, and conical papillae covering most of the tongue's dorsal surface. They do not contain taste buds; instead, they aid in mechanical functions such as food manipulation.

Foliate papillae (Option D): Located on the lateral margins of the tongue as vertical folds. Contain numerous taste buds but are less developed in humans.

Reference:

Anatomy, Head and Neck, Tongue Taste Buds - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: Name the type of joint marked in the following image
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Articulating surfaces between malleus and incus are saddle-shaped i.e. one surface is convex while the other is concave.
  • Saddle synovial joint:
    • Examples include
      • Joint between malleus and incus.
      • Sternoclavicular joint.
      • 1st carpometacarpal joint.
      • Calcaneocuboid joint.

Gliding Joint (Option D):

  • Examples: Lateral end of clavicle and acromion process (acromioclavicular joint).
  • Gliding joints (also known as plane joints) have flat surfaces that glide or slide past each other.
  • They allow for limited movement in various directions, such as sliding or twisting.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is derived from the marked point in the given image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Structures derived from the paraxial mesoderm include the somites.
  • Somites are bilaterally paired blocks of mesoderm that form on either side of the neural tube during early embryonic development.
  • The somites give rise to various structures in the embryo, including the axial skeleton (such as vertebrae), skeletal muscles, and the dermis of the skin.

Intraembryonic Mesoderm/ Secondary Mesoderm:

  • Formed by the proliferation of cells from the primitive streak.
  • Separates the ectoderm and endoderm except in specific regions that remain bilaminar throughout life:
    • Prochordal plate (future oral cavity)
    • Cloacal membrane (future anal and urogenital openings)
    • Midline caudal to the prochordal plate
  • Subdivisions:

Somites:

  • Paraxial mesoderm becomes segmented to form 42-44 pairs of somites develop on either side of the neural tube and notochord.
  • Appear between the 20th and 30th day, marking the 4th week as the somite period.
  • Somite Structure:
    • Sclerotome: Ventromedial part; forms vertebral column and ribs.
    • Dermatome: Lateral part; forms dermis of skin and subcutaneous tissue.
    • Myotome: Intermediate part; forms striated muscle.

Kidneys (Option B): Kidneys are the derivatives of the intermediate mesoderm.

Dorsal root ganglion (Option C): Dorsal root ganglia are derived from the neural crest cells.

Parietal pleura (Option D): The pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal cavities, housing vital organs, originate from the lateral plate mesoderm during embryonic development.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546679/#

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10380231/#:

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Terminal bronchioles differ from larger bronchi as they are devoid of cartilage in their walls.
  • The ciliated cells are still present in terminal bronchioles, but their abundance is reduced.
  • Additionally, terminal bronchioles exhibit alveolar outgrowths, marking the transition to structures involved in gas exchange.

Explanation of other options:

Respiratory bronchus (Option A):

  • Respiratory bronchioles have alveoli budding directly from their walls. This is a distinctive feature that indicates their role in gas exchange.
  • Epithelium may become more cuboidal, eventually transitioning to simple squamous epithelium in the alveoli.
  • Similar to terminal bronchioles, respiratory bronchioles lack cartilage in their walls.

Alveolar sac (Option C):

  • Alveolar sacs are composed of clusters of alveoli, which are small, balloon-like structures.
  • Alveolar walls are extremely thin to facilitate efficient gas exchange.

Intrapulmonary bronchus (Option D):

  • Intrapulmonary bronchi have smooth muscle in their walls, which helps regulate airflow.
  • Goblet cells, found in the epithelium of intrapulmonary bronchi, secrete mucus to aid in capturing particles and facilitating their expulsion from the respiratory tract.
  • Cartilage found in the intrapulmonary bronchus helps maintain the shape of the bronchi, preserving the integrity of the airway structure.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK534789/

questions.text: Identify the histological image below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cells towards the lumen are umbrella shaped (Globular).
  • Basement membrane is straight.
  • Transitional epithelium is found in the bladder and ureters.
  • The cells may also have multiple nuclei and a scalloped appearance at the free surface.

Explanation of other options:

Pseudostratified columnar epithelium (Option A):

  • This tissue appears layered, but all cells are attached to the basement membrane.
  • Look for nuclei located at different levels and the presence of cilia on the apical surface.

Non-keratinized squamous epithelium (Option B):

  • This tissue comprises layers of flat cells.
  • Look for nuclei located towards the basal surface and the absence of keratin

Stratified squamous epithelium (Option C):

  • This tissue comprises multiple layers of flat cells, but the outermost layer is dead and keratinized.
  • Look for flattened cells at the surface that lack nuclei and contain keratin.

questions.text: A patient presents with a cyst on the neck anterior to the sternocleidomastoid at the junction of the upper and middle third of the muscle. This cyst is due to the persistence of which of the following embryological clefts?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The second pharyngeal cleft is located between the second and third pharyngeal arches
  • It normally gives rise to the cervical sinus, a transient structure that contributes to the development of the tonsillar fossa and palatine tonsils. However, the persistence of the second cleft can lead to the formation of a branchial cyst

Explanation of other options:

1st cleft (Option A): The 1st pharyngeal cleft, located between the first and second pharyngeal arches, typically forms the external auditory meatus. However, its persistence doesn't lead to cyst formation in this area.

3rd cleft (Option C): The 3rd pharyngeal cleft, found between the third and fourth pharyngeal arches, doesn't lead to cyst formation in the described location if it persists.

4th cleft (Option D): The fourth and fifth pharyngeal clefts contribute to forming structures in the head and neck. If the fourth cleft persists, it doesn't cause cyst formation as described.

choices.text: Lateral nasal prominence and maxillary prominence
Lateral nasal prominence and mandibular prominence
Medial nasal prominence and maxillary prominence
Medial nasal prominence and mandibular prominence

questions.text: The following condition is seen in the image results from the failure of fusion of which prominence
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The failure of fusion between the medial nasal prominence and maxillary prominence can result in cleft lip and cleft palate, as well as other facial malformations.
  • A cleft lip is when there is a gap or split in the upper lip, while a cleft palate is when there is a gap or split in the roof of the mouth.
  • These malformations can occur on one or both sides of the face and can range in severity.

Lateral nasal prominence and maxillary prominence (Option A): The failure of fusion between them can result in various congenital malformations, including oblique facial cleft

Lateral nasal prominence and mandibular prominence (Option B): The lateral nasal prominence doesn't fuse with the mandibular prominence during embryonic development, leading to possible facial malformations.

Medial nasal prominence and mandibular prominence (Option D): The failure of fusion between them can result in various malformations

questions.text: Given below is the microscopic view of a lamellar bone. Identify the marked structure
questions.solution:
Volkmann's canals (perforating canals) are transverse or oblique passageways in compact bone.

They connect adjacent Haversian canals and transmit blood vessels & nerves from the periosteum into the bone.

They differ from Haversian canals in that they are not encircled by concentric lamellae and do not run parallel to the long axis of the bone.



Explanation of Other Options:

Haversian canal (Option B): Runs longitudinally at the center of each osteon, parallel to the bone's long axis, surrounded by concentric lamellae..

Canaliculi (Option C): Microscopic channels radiating from lacunae, connecting osteocytes with each other and with the Haversian canal; not visible as large dark canals.

Lacunae (Option D): Small cavities between lamellae housing osteocytes; appear as tiny dark spaces and lack vessels/nerves.

questions.text: The given finding is associated with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Trisomy 21, commonly known as Down syndrome, results from an extra copy of chromosome 21. People with Down syndrome often have distinct facial features, intellectual disabilities, and certain medical problems. Approximately half of individuals with Down syndrome have a single transverse palmar crease, making this the correct answer. The simian crease is relatively common in Down syndrome.

Down's syndrome, caused by trisomy 21, is associated with multiple systemic manifestations due to the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21.

  • This is due to meiotic nondisjunction in either maternal or paternal gamete.
  • Occurs at a frequency of 1:800 to 1:1000 newborns.

The overexpression of genes located on chromosome 21 contributes to the clinical features.

Clinical Features and Diagnosis:

General Features:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Flat facial profile, upward-slanting eyes with epicanthic folds, oblique palpebral fissure (visible when eyes are open).
  • Small nose with flat nasal bridge
  • Narrow palate, small teeth, and furrowed, protruding tongue
  • Significant hypotonia
  • Small, brachycephalic skull with flat occiput, and small, dysplastic ears
  • Short, broad hands with clinodactyly (hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the fifth finger)
  • Simian crease on the palm
  • A wide gap between the first and second toes (sandal gap)

Comorbidities

  • Congenital Heart Disease: 40% of children have congenital heart defects, primarily endocardial cushion defects (40-60% of cases) - AVSD, VSD, ASD, PDA, TOF. Early cardiac evaluation is crucial.
  • Gastrointestinal Malformations: 12% have atresias, especially duodenal atresia. There is an increased risk of annular pancreas and Hirschsprung disease.
  • Ophthalmic Problems: Increased risk of cataracts, nystagmus, strabismus, and visual acuity issues. Regular eye evaluations are advised from infancy onward.
  • Hearing Defects: 40-60% experience conductive hearing loss, often due to serous otitis media in the first year. Routine hearing assessments are recommended before 6 months of age and annually.
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Hypothyroidism occurs in 13-54% of patients.
  • Atlanto-occipital Subluxation: Incidence ranges from 10-30%. A lateral neck radiograph is recommended.
  • Physical Growth: Linear growth is typically slower, and children may become obese with age. Muscle tone often improves, but regular monitoring of height and weight is necessary.
  • Malignancies: Increased risk of lymphoproliferative disorders, such as acute lymphoblastic leukemia, acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplasia, and transient lymphoproliferative syndrome.
  • Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease: The APP gene, located on chromosome 21, plays a significant role in amyloid plaque formation, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.

Explanation of other options:

Trisomy 13 (Option A): Trisomy 13, or Patau syndrome, results from an extra chromosome 13, leading to severe developmental issues and congenital abnormalities. While hand anomalies are common, a simian crease isn't typically present.

Klinefelter's syndrome (Option C): Klinefelter's syndrome in males with an extra X chromosome (XXY) leads to male hypogonadism and physical differences, but it's not usually linked to a simian crease.

Trisomy 18 (Option D): Trisomy 18, or Edwards syndrome, stems from an extra chromosome 18, leading to severe developmental delays, intellectual disabilities, and congenital anomalies. While hand abnormalities may occur, a simian crease isn't a defining trait.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with swelling due to a collection of blood around the eyes after sustaining a head injury. Which structural attachment is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • When a person sustains a head injury, especially around the eyes, blood can collect in the surrounding tissues due to ruptured blood vessels. The blood can accumulate in the subcutaneous space, causing swelling. The structural attachment that can contribute to this condition is the aponeurosis attachment.

The scalp is made up of five layers:

  1. Skin-hairy and has numerous sweat glands and sebaceous glands
  2. Superficial fascia (Connective tissue)-provides a medium for vessels and nerves to pass to the skin
  3. Deep fascia in the form of the epicranial aponeurosis or galea aponeurotica with the occipitofrontalis muscle
  4. Loose areolar tissue-provides passage for emissary veins connecting extracranial veins to intracranial venous sinuses
  5. Pericranium

Explanation of other options:

Periosteum (Option B): The periosteum is a tough connective tissue layer on bone surfaces. It aids in bone health but isn't directly linked to swelling around the eyes from head injuries.

Cellulitis (Option C): Cellulitis, a bacterial skin infection, doesn't typically lead to blood collection and swelling post-head injury.

None of the above (Option D): The correct answer is A. Aponeurosis attachment, as explained above. Therefore, the option "None of the above" is not the correct answer in this context.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient underwent an endoscopic examination of the gastrointestinal tract due to recurrent abdominal discomfort and altered bowel habits. Identify the arrow-marked structure in the given image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given histology slide is of duodenum.
  • Identification points:
    • Wall made up of four layers.
    • Mucosa - presence of numerous broad villi lined by simple columnar epithelium with microvilli and goblet cells.
    • Presence of crypts of lieberkuhn
    • Presence of submucous Brunner's gland.
  • The marked structure by the arrow is of Brunner's gland.

Intestinal Cells of Kajal (Option B): Incorrect term (likely a misinterpretation of interstitial cells of Cajal, which regulate gut motility).

Crypts of Lieberkühn (Option C): Present in the duodenum but are located in the mucosa, whereas Brunner's glands are in the submucosa.

Peyer's Patch (Option D): Found in the ileum, not the duodenum.

questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below gives rise to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The structure marked A in the image is a falciform ligament.
  • This broad, lean, mesentery-like structure connects the liver to the anterior abdominal wall and separates the right and left lobes of the liver.

questions.text: Identify the given structure.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pancreatic islet cells are clusters of endocrine cells within the pancreas that secrete hormones such as insulin and glucagon.
  • Pancreatic islet cells are also known as islets of Langerhans. Each islet comprises a few distinctive sorts of cells, including alpha, beta, delta, and PP cells that work together to direct blood glucose levels.
  • The islet cells are organized in a round or unpredictably molded cluster and are encompassed by a thin layer of connective tissue.

Explanation of other options:

Lymph node (Option A): Composed of a cortex with follicles, paracortex, and medulla containing lymphoid tissue, not endocrine cell clusters.

Glomerulus (Option B): Refers to a tuft of capillaries in the kidney that participates in filtration; structurally very different from islets.

Spleen (Option C): Contains red pulp and white pulp, organized around central arteries, not small clusters of endocrine cells.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7565096/

questions.text: Identify the cartilage given below
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • It is a cartilage with collagen fibers arranged in parallel bundles, giving it its characteristic strength and unbending nature.
  • White fibrocartilage is found in zones of the body where strength and support are required, such as the intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, and menisci of the knee.

questions.text: The anomaly demonstrated in the image is due to a developmental defect in which of the following pharyngeal arch arteries?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The condition shown in the image is Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), a congenital heart defect where the ductus arteriosus (a fetal blood vessel connecting the pulmonary artery to the aorta) fails to close after birth.

  • The ductus arteriosus is derived from the left 6th pharyngeal arch artery.

questions.text: Which of the following adult structures arises from the embryonic structure indicated in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure is the allantois, a hindgut diverticulum. It forms the urachus during fetal development, connecting the bladder apex to the umbilicus, which later degenerates into the median umbilical ligament. This ligament runs along the midline of the abdominal wall.


Meckel's diverticulum (Option C): This arises from the vitelline duct, not the urachus.

Reference: Urachal remnant causing umbilical in-drawing during micturition - PMC

questions.text: The marked structure in the image arises from the development of which of the following embryological components?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure marked in the image corresponds to the deep inguinal ring, a key anatomical feature of the inguinal canal.

  • The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the fascia transversalis, located just above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament. This defect allows the passage of the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament of the uterus in females.

choices.text: Left colic vein and middle colic vein
Oesophageal veins and left gastric veins

questions.text: A patient with a known history of liver cirrhosis presents with abdominal pain, jaundice, and signs of portal hypertension. Which of the following venous anastomoses is most likely to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has portal hypertension, which is commonly associated with liver cirrhosis.

  • Portal hypertension leads to the development of portosystemic anastomoses, which are connections between the portal vein and systemic venous circulation.
  • One significant site of such an anastomosis is between the oesophageal veins (draining into the systemic circulation via the azygos vein) andthe left gastric vein (draining into the portal vein).
  • In portal hypertension, increased pressure in the portal vein causes blood to flow through these collateral veins, leading to oesophageal varices.

Portal Hypertension: Reversal of blood flow away from the portal vein due to high pressure.

Clinical Features:

  • Splenomegaly
  • Ascites
  • Esophageal varices
  • Rectal varices
  • Caput medusae

Explanation for other options:

Left colic vein and middle colic veins (Option A): These veins are part of the portal circulation and do not form portosystemic anastomoses.

Superior and phrenic veins (Option C): These are systemic veins and do not involve the portal system.

Sigmoid and superior rectal veins (Option D): both are part of the portal circulation but don't drain into the systemic circulation; thus, anastomoses between them aren't seen in portal hypertension.

questions.text: A patient complains of pain radiating down the posterior thigh and leg following a heavy lifting episode. Which spinal nerve root is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The S1 nerve root is most commonly associated with pain radiating down the posterior leg, including the hamstring and calf muscles.

  • The patient is presenting with pain in the back of the thigh and leg after lifting heavy weights, which is consistent with sciatica-like pain.
  • The S1 root is responsible for innervating the muscles of the posterior thigh and the calf, and it is often affected in cases of sciatica, particularly after heavy lifting or straining.

Explanation for other options:

L4 (Option A): Because L4 is more likely to cause pain radiating to the anterior thigh and knee, rather than the posterior thigh and leg.

L5 (Option B) Because L5 involvement typically causes pain that radiates to the lateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot.

S2 (Option D): While S2 may be involved in some cases of sciatica, S1 is more commonly associated with posterior leg pain.

questions.text: During which developmental week does the human heart begin to beat?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The heart begins to beat at approximately 21 days of gestation, which corresponds to the 4th week of development.

questions.text: Nervi Furcalis is related to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • L4 root bifurcates into 2 parts. One part supplies lumbar plexus. The other part joins with L5 fibres and supply sacral plexus. Hence it is known as nervifurcalis.

choices.text: Failure in closure of anterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of posterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of complete neural tube
Failure in closure of caudal neuropore of neural tube

questions.text: What is the embryological basis of the developmental defect shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image depicts anencephaly, a serious neural tube defect resulting from failure of the anterior (rostral) neuropore to close by around day 25 of gestation. This defect leads to absence of major portions of the brain and skull, leaving exposed neural tissue.

Affected infants often present with cranial vault defects and may show feeding difficulties due to impaired neurological function.

Neural Tube Defects (NTDs) and Neuropore Closure Defects:

Explanation of other options:

Failure in closure of posterior neuropore (Option B): Incorrect because it causes spina bifida, affecting the spinal cord and vertebral column, not the brain.

Failure in closure of the complete neural tube (Option C): Incorrect because it results in craniorachischisis, a lethal defect where both the brain and spinal cord remain open.

Failure in closure of caudal neuropore (Option D): Incorrect because it leads to spina bifida occulta, a mild defect limited to the lower spine, not affecting brain development

questions.text: A young child presents with hypocalcemic tetany and absent thymic shadow on imaging. Clinical evaluation reveals signs of hypoparathyroidism. Based on the developmental origin, which labeled area in the diagram of the pharyngeal pouches is likely defective?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical features are characteristic of DiGeorge syndrome, a disorder due to abnormal development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches, most commonly affecting the 3rd pouch.
  • The third pharyngeal pouch gives rise to:
    • Thymus → T-cell immunity
    • Inferior parathyroid glands → Calcium homeostasis
  • Failure of proper development leads to:
    • Thymic aplasia → T-cell immunodeficiency
    • Parathyroid hypoplasia or aplasia → Hypocalcemia and tetany
  • The fourth pouch forms the superior parathyroid glands and the ultimobranchial body (which forms C-cells of the thyroid), but it is less commonly affected.

Pharyngeal Pouch Derivatives:


DiGeorge Syndrome:

  • Cause: Deletion of 22q11.2, leading to defective neural crest migration
  • CATCH-22
    • Cardiac defects (Tetralogy of Fallot, truncus arteriosus)
    • Abnormal face
    • Thymic aplasia (T-cell immunodeficiency)
    • Cleft palate
    • Hypocalcemia (due to parathyroid agenesis)
    • 22q11.2 deletion

Explanation of other options:

1. (Option A):Forms structures in the ear; not involved in thymus/parathyroid development.

2. (Option B):Forms palatine tonsils; not involved in calcium or immune regulation.

4. (Option D):Affects superior parathyroids, but major DiGeorge defects arise from the 3rd pouch.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neural crest cells (NCCs) originate from the embryonic ectoderm and migrate to form a diverse range of tissues including:

  • Sensory and autonomic ganglia
  • Melanocytes
  • Schwann cells
  • Facial cartilage
  • Certain eye structures

However, the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is not a neural crest derivative. It arises from the outer layer of the optic cup, which in turn develops from the neural tube-derived neuroectoderm.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Corpora amylacea are small, rounded, lamellated structures commonly found in the brain (especially near ventricles and in subpial regions) and in the prostate. They are typically:

  • PAS-positive
  • Composed of glycoproteins and polysaccharides
  • Often eosinophilic or basophilic on H&E stain
  • Considered non-pathological, frequently associated with aging and chronic neurodegeneration


Explanation of other options:

Corpora arenacea (Option B) also known as brain sand, these are calcified concretions seen in the pineal gland, not in the brain parenchyma or prostate.

Lewy body (Option C) are intracytoplasmic inclusions rich in α-synuclein, characteristic of Parkinson's disease and dementia with Lewy bodies. Histologically, they appear as eosinophilic spherical inclusions within neurons.

Psammoma bodies (Option D) are concentrically laminated calcifications, seen in tumors like papillary thyroid carcinoma, serous papillary ovarian carcinoma, and meningiomas. They are pathological and composed mainly of calcium.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6375970/

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6303404/

questions.text: Which of the following is the first structure formed by migration of epiblast cells through the primitive streak?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During gastrulation, epiblast cells migrate through the primitive streak to form the three germ layers.

  • The first migrating cells move inward and displace the hypoblast, giving rise to the definitive endoderm.
  • The next wave forms the intraembryonic mesoderm.
  • Epiblast cells that do not migrate remain as the ectoderm.


Explanation of other options:

Cardiac mesoderm (Option B): Derived from mesoderm, which forms after endoderm.

Epidermis (Option C): Ectodermal in origin; ectoderm forms after migration is complete.

Neural groove (Option D): A product of ectodermal folding during neurulation, well after germ layer formation.

questions.text: From which of the following is nucleus pulposus formed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A - Neural Tube
  • B - Paraxial Mesoderm
  • C - Notochord
  • D - Intermediate Mesoderm

Remnant of Notochord - Nucleus Pulposus, Apical ligament of Dens and Membrana tectoria.

questions.text: Ejaculatory duct is derived from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Derivatives of Wolffian duct/Mesonephric duct :

  • Epididymis
  • Seminal vescicle
  • Ejaculatory duct
  • Ductus deferens

choices.text: Arch of aorta in between left common carotid artery and left subclavian artery

questions.text: Fate of 6th aortic arch:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Proximal part of 6th arch artery forms pulmonary artery.
  • Distal part of left 6th arch artery forms ductus arteriosus

questions.text: The type of joint present between Epiphysis & Diaphysis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pimary cartilaginous joint/Synchondrosis

Examples :

  • Between epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone (Epiphyseal plate)
  • All costochondral joints
